Habeas Corpus
The complaint herein 1 alleges that: Plaintiff is mother of a minor child by former huband and is the natural and lawful Guardian therof and entitled to the custody of said child.
2 That she obtained a decree of divorce in the circuit court of Oregon from her former husband in 1869. Whereby the custody of the child was awarded her.
3 That the child is the of this court
4 That since decree she was lawfully with Gahres
5 That she and her husband have ample means of supporting and schooling the child

6 That she is in custody of defendants and that her education is neglected and that Defendants wrongfully retain custody of said child.

In the case in 25 March of page 94 the Chancellor says
The proceeding on Habeas Corpus principle of re adjudication is applicable to proceedings on Habeas Corpus and that it make no difference
in the application that the whether the writ was before a court or Judge. for in neither case ought the party to be to proceed adjudication before the same court or officer. to the former decision while the remained the same.

I am to think that the reasonable and at all made . I think the result would be evil. Were I to reverse a decision made by a former Judge of this court which is clearly re adjudication.
if new facts or issues are prescribed the case is exactly the same in all aspects.
I am of opinion that on Habeas Corpus in a case with the facts as in this case of law The judge can only determine who is legally entitled to the custody of this child
That is on wherin thus the law. bestowed the child
True as say where a court a decree of divorce that court may force time to time as the facts may but no such charge has been made in fact as the child is without the jurisdiction of the Oregon Courts. it is any order of that court would be of any but it is not now necessary to determine the
I am of opinion also that this court has no original jurisdiction in matters of guardianship. that is conferred on the court of Probate which has ample power to appoint and guardians for any and all minors within the Territory on a proper case made and from such orders are to this court.
617 of our statue declares that no ward or Judge shall require the any judgement or process whereby a party is in custody upon any process issued on any prior judgement of a court of jurisdiction
and 628 applies this provision to suits relative to minors
have seen that the judge in Habeas Corpus has the of a court
Wherefore looking
at the whole case I am of opinion that the judgement of his Honor Judge Kennedy awarding the child to the defendants is a to this proceeding
The plea is therefore sufficient and the writ writ be dismissed
